author: Marinda Louw-Coetzee
title: Mount Kilimanjaro for dummies
text:
Mount Kilimanjaro for dummies Fri, 14 Aug 2015 11:41 AM Share Mount Kilimanjaro. Credit: flickr.com/ Tambako The Jaguar 
The highest free-standing mountain in the world? Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa. Many people try to climb it every year. Most of them make it. 
But there are still many people in the dark about the experience. Luckily, we have all the introductory information you need. 
What is Kilimanjaro? 
Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcano in Tanzania in East Africa. The mountain has three volcanic cones - Shira, Mawenzi and Kibo. Kibo is the big brother and it is the dormant cone, while the others are extinct. Credit: Taher Nassrulla 
Kili is the highest mountain in Africa and the highest freestanding mountain in the world. 
Being freestanding, it is not part of a mountain range. Uhuru peak is the highest spot (5985m) and is on the rim of the Kibo crater. 
Why should I go there? 
It is a bucket-list adventure. You can walk to the top of the mountain without climbing gear to stand on the edge of a crater while the sun rises over Africa. See the big migration of wildebeests in the Serengeti and dive on coral reefs a few days later - all in Tanzania. 
How does it work? 
There are six routes to the top, but only four are regularly used. The most popular is Machame and Marangu, while Rongai and Lemosho are beautiful and quieter alternatives. Marangu is the only route where you will sleep in rustic huts. On the other routes, a tent will be set up for you by porters. Credit: Taher Nassrulla 
You have to be accompanied by a registered guide. Your backpack will be carried by porters and a cook will prepare delicious 3-course meals and hot drinks. Routes vary in length, but you can spend between five and eight days on the mountain. 
Is it safe? 
Yes. There are no dangerous animals on the mountain and mosquitoes do not operate at a high altitude. You might be cold and tired, but you will never be in serious physical danger unless you ignore your body's reaction to the altitude. 
Altitude sickness is the biggest threat to your wellbeing on the mountain. Symptoms include nausea, headaches, loss of appetite and tiredness. 
Is it cheap? 
To be honest, no. First off, you will have to pay for a flight to Tanzani. 
Secondly, the trekking fees are high, mainly due to the Kilimanjaro National Park fees which cost about $130 per person per day. Park fees make up about 50% of a trekking tour's cost. 
Tipping the crew is also standard. Your porters, guide and cooks will expect it as it is the main source of their income. Budget for an amount of 10% of the tour price. Credit: Taher Nassrulla 
A tour price should include all park fees, good equipment (tents, mess tent, sleeping mats, cutlery etc), experienced hiking crew, a climbing permit, camping fees, a first-aid kit and two nights' accommodation before and after the climb. 
How do I get there? 
You can fly to Dar es Salaam (Tanzania) or Nairobi (Kenya) and then to Kilimanjaro International Airport. There you will be met by the tour operator's driver. Most trekking tours include this service as well as a night's accommodation before and after the tour. 
How do I get around? 
You will be taken to the gate closest to the starting point of your route. This will be done by the tour operator's driver. When you are safely down from the mountain, you will be met by the driver and taken back to the hotel you stayed at before the trek. 
If you want to tour Tanzania, choose a safari that includes a driver-guide. Tanzania is not suitable for self-drive trips. 
How long do I stay? 
Depending on the route you choose to Kili's summit, you will spend five to seven nights on the mountain. The more time you spend at high altitude, the better your body copes with the height above sea level - improving your chances of reaching the summit. 
After spending money on a flight to Tanzania, most travellers join a safari for a few days after the trek. Some others prefer to rest a while on the beaches of Zanzibar. Make sure to take two to three weeks off work. 
How do I prepare? 
Anyone can do it, but being fit makes it more enjoyable. Climb stairs, walk with a small daypack (with about 3kg in weight inside) and wear in your hiking boots. Do research on the various routes and choose a good operator. Speak to people who have done it. 
What else should I know? 
Most gear can be rented from outfitters in Moshi, the 'trekking base town' in Tanzania, but bring your own well-worn hiking boots and sleeping bag. Fleece and thermal clothing, a day backpack, some snacks, a first-aid kit and willpower are essential. In addition, you will need US dollar cash (tipping), extra batteries for your camera and a sense of humor. Choose a tour operator with experience guides, who treats their porters well and has quality, clean equipment. You will be cold and sore yet ecstatic, with a tremendous feeling of accomplishment. The minimum age is 10. There are many people on the mountain and you will often see a string of hikers on the trail in front of you. There are no showers or toilets. You will get a certificate to confirm your achievement. 
Hiking to the top of the highest mountain in Africa is an expensive, bucket-list adventure that can be done by anyone from the age of 10. 
Combine it with a lodge or camping safari for an all-round out-of-Africa experience. 
If you're interested, speak to the people at Kilimanjaro-Experience.com . They speak Afrikaans, English and German. Related Articles
